Message.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth
Message.Msg: "The integer unit can do two integer operations per cycle and has separate pipelines for load and store. The core also sports its own floating point/SIMD unit, which has an out-of-order scheduler that can push through one operation per cycle, plus a load and a store. The FP unit can do 128-bit processing, but since there is only one unit, it cannot be double-pumped to emulate Intel's and AMD's AVX vector math instructions. (That would be a nice feature for X-Gene 2.0.) What we now know about X-Gene is that it uses a two-core module as the basic building block of the processor. Each core has its own L1 data and L1 instruction cache, and there is a shared L2 cache that spans these two ARM cores. The core has a four-wide, out-of-order execution unit for integer work, and includes full virtualization support including nested page tables. This is a feature that x86 hypervisors make use of to boost the performance of virtual machines running atop hypervisors like VMware's ESXi, Citrix Systems' Xen, Red Hat's KVM, and Microsoft's Hyper-V. And it means that any of these hypervisors can be ported from x86 to X-Gene processors – and probably will be in the long run, if ARM servers take off"

Bernanke Says Fed May Boost Economy By Susanna Kim @skimm Follow on Twitter Aug 31, 2012 1:24pmBernanke Says Fed May Boost Economy Email 0 Smaller Font Text Larger Text | Print (Credit: Ted S. Warren/AP Photo) Chairman Ben Bernanke defended the Federal Reserve’s past stimulus actions in a speech on Friday morning, saying its actions “can be effective” and more of them may be on the way. Bernanke’s keynote speech at the Federal Reserve of Kansas City’s Economic Symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo. was closely watched by investors for clues of additional stimulus in the form of quantitative easing, which at its simplest level aims to increase the monetary supply after the central bank buys government securities. Though Bernanke did not announce any new Federal Reserve policies or strategies, he made clear the central bank would be open to additional action in the future.

Topic.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth

Message.Msg: I am not sure how reducing the instruction set "make a lot of sense". You will have to explain that more. The ARM THUMB instruction set is hardly "RISC" and is essentially the ARM "CISC" encoding of the ARM instruction set. Reducing the size of the instruction set introduces some difficult problems too. A RISC instruction set generates a program with a code footprint that is larger than its CISC counterpart. The larger code size means that less of a program will fit into a dedicated code cache. That means that the code footprint will consume more of any unified larger coherrent cache. Which means that there will be less room for data in those unified outer caches. Less data in the cache means a higher miss rate and program stalls as it waits for data back from memory. Memory IO will require the larger IO buffers which consume more power. ARM recognized this problem and patched in the THUMB instruction set which is hardly RISC. The x86 has been internally "RISC" for a number of generations. They have a front end instruction decoder that expands the instructions into their RISC engine format. Think of it more as COMPRESSED program code and an x86 front end DECOMPRESSION engine.

Topic.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth

Message.Msg: good points... but the extra wide issues, and further distribute blocks of code... based on dependencies... This couldn't be done like this before with variable length instructions... or at least without a longer pipe with more latencies... Variable length has its advantages, but the above is an advantage of Fixed length instructions The apps will be the same, but take advantage of the new modern compilers...

Message.Title: HP ditches ARM for Intel for all kinds of reasons
Message.Msg: HP Project Moonshot ditches ARM for Intel If you recall, HP’s Project Moonshot was an attempt ot create an ultra low-power server using ARM’s Calxeda, allowing the company to pack a large number of servers into a single rack unit. Now it looks like HP has decided to move in a different direction, announcing that it will be using Intel’s “Centerton” Atom chips instead. HP say they went with Atom due to the 64-bit support, hardware virtualization, low power requirements, and a broader software ecosystem.

But the Ryan campaign confirmed to Runner's World that he has only run one marathon, the 1990 Grandma’s Marathon in Duluth, Minnesota, which he finished in just over 4 hours.

Topic.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth

Message.Msg: I think I understand what you are saying. You are saying that 4 instruction can be loaded and executed in parallel and that is tough to do if you don't know how long the instructions are. With the fixed length instruction, 4 can be loaded and executed in parallel. The average number will likely be far less than 4-instructions because of a number of things. DATA DEPENDENCY between instructions will stall execution. Few programs can avoid this problem. There is not much a compiler can do. BRANCHES TAKEN will cause some vacant slots. The CPU has to prepare and expect the branch NOT TAKEN case. The average number of instructions between branches taken is not very high. In the single digits, I think. 6 to 8 instructions between branch taken would not be far off. It will be interesting to see what they try to overcome these problems. I think there will be less benefit that they have predicted. I expect they will be using the "performance per watt" metrics. Those comparisons are going to be tougher every day. Haswell numbers are going to make it fun.

Message.Title: Microsoft fails to pacify PC vendors about Surface tablets
Message.Msg: From Digitimes: To ease the impact created by its WoA Surface tablet PC, Microsoft has been negotiating with brand vendors including Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Dell since July hoping to pacify them; however, Microsoft has not been able to provide a satisfactory solution, and HP has already decided to halt development of Windows RT tablet PCs, while Dell reportedly may also back away from the segment, according to sources from the upstream supply chain. As HP and Dell may both halt their Windows RT tablet PC production, their processor supplier Qualcomm is expected to be seriously affected. Texas Instruments (TI) also recently lost its orders from Toshiba because of the vendor's decision to stop development of Windows RT tablet PCs. Nvidia, which is supplying its solution for Surface, may be the only chipmaker to benefit from the Windows RT tablet PC market, the sources noted. Although Microsoft had been trying to convince its partners that Surface is meant to increase the penetration of Windows RT and help them enlarge the Windows RT market, most brand vendors do not agree with Microsoft's assessment.

Topic.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth

Message.Msg: Simplifying the instruction set that your microprocessor supports simplifies the micro-architecture needed to realize that instruction set. If you start with a CISC instruction set and based on what you've observed on the software (usage) side, if you pare it down to its bare essentials, the number of circuits you'll need to realize your instruction set (OPs) will reduce significantly from the CISC you started with. Simplifying right at the top (at the instruction set set definition stage) makes things simpler at every subsequent stage. This makes a lot of sense. Intel stuck with CISC for backward compatibility.
